# ✨ Rohandsey – High Elf Cleric
* **Race & Class:** High Elf Cleric
* **Personality:** Charismatic, eccentric, and permanently a bit dazed. He balances between tragic and comedic, haunted by his past while stumbling forward in a concussed haze.

## 🌄 Early Life in the Mountains
Rohandsey was born in a poor, high-elf town deep in the mountains. As a teenager he began wearing **women’s clothing**, not out of preference at first, but because they were cheaper. This made him an outsider, mocked by the townsfolk.
At 14, he had a fling with a girl, who fell pregnant. To protect her from her strict religious family, Rohandsey **pretended he had given birth to the baby himself**. Combined with his eccentric clothing, the townsfolk believed a **miracle had occurred** and that he was touched by God.

## 🕯️ From Miracle to Messiah
This “miracle” drew him into the town’s secretive, “classier” orgies, where his reputation grew. By his 16th summer, Rohandsey was dabbling in alchemy, creating **crude methamphetamines** that he fed to fellow revelers. The drugs caused memory loss, and when women later discovered themselves pregnant, the village believed Rohandsey was responsible for a series of **virgin births**.
Rohandsey’s fame snowballed—he became a living **prophet-figure**, revered by many, feared by some.

## 🎪 The World Rohandsey Festival Disaster
His notoriety culminated in a series of gatherings known as the **World Rohandsey Festivals**. At the fourth, Rohandsey arrived late—by then, all his followers had taken a bad batch of his meth. Every one of them was dead by the time he appeared, including the mother of his child.
Overwhelmed and terrified, Rohandsey **abandoned his toddler** and fled. The survivors of his hometown were furious, demanding he pay **parenting costs** and restitution for the disaster.

## 🚶 Life on the Run
Since then, Rohandsey has drifted from town to town, funding his escape through **meth-cooking and small-time cult manipulation**. His body and mind bear the scars: he lives in a **permanent, mildly concussed state** from years of drug use.
To cover himself, and perhaps to redeem himself, he took up the mantle of a **cleric**. His faith is a strange mixture of genuine devotion and self-delusion: is he truly chosen, or just a fraud with divine magic? Even he doesn’t fully know.


## 🎭 Present Motivations
* **Redemption or Escape:** Rohandsey travels with the Piss Bandits partly to do good, partly to hide from those chasing him.
* **Fear of the Past:** He is constantly looking over his shoulder, waiting for debts, abandoned family, or old followers to reappear.
* **Dangerous Knowledge:** His cult and drug history give him a twisted insight into how manipulation and altered states of mind shape belief—knowledge that makes him oddly useful against Far Realm cults like the Purple Robes.

## 🎲 The Rohandsey Trouble Table
Rohandsey’s past is never far behind. When you want chaos to catch up to him, roll a **d8**:
| d8 | Trouble                  | Description & Hook                                                                                                        |
| -- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 1  | **Debt Collector**       | A bounty hunter or priest demands “parenting costs” for the abandoned child. They threaten trial or seize gear if unpaid. |  Effect: Rohandsey must pay 100 gp per level or risk trial/seizure of equipment.
| 2  | **Fanatical Follower**   | An ex-follower arrives, treating Rohandsey as a messiah and loudly spreading his gospel.|  Effect: Rohandsey makes a DC 15 Charisma (Persuasion or Deception) check to defuse the chaos, or the follower draws a mob’s attention.
| 3  | **The Abandoned Child**  | His child (now older) appears, demanding answers—or repayment in gold, blood, or love.|  Effect: The child demands either 500 gp in support or a quest of atonement. If refused, they may become a recurring rival.
| 4  | **Bad Batch**            | Someone finds one of Rohandsey’s old meth recipes; deaths or visions ensue, and the party gets blamed.|  Effect: Rohandsey makes a DC 14 Medicine or Arcana check to stabilize victims. Failure earns the party disfavor with local authorities.
| 5  | **Festival Survivor**    | A villager who lived through World Rohandsey Festival 4 seeks vengeance—or wants to crown him again.|  Effect: 50% chance they’re out for vengeance, 50% chance they want to restore Rohandsey’s cult.
| 6  | **Cult Revival**         | A splinter sect has restarted World Rohandsey Festivals. They want him to lead—or they’ll force him.|  Effect: If refused, they attempt a hostile kidnapping ritual at night.
| 7  | **Concussive Flashback** | Rohandsey relives his drug-fueled past mid-adventure, blurting secrets or performing cult rituals by mistake.|  Effect: For the next 1d4 hours, he has disadvantage on Insight and Concentration checks, but advantage on Performance (as he relives “godhood”).
| 8  | **Fey Tie-In**           | Whispers call him “the Twice-Born.” A Fey Lord takes interest, sending agents to “return him home.” |  Effect: Treat as a CR-appropriate Fey encounter, with Rohandsey as the target. Negotiation may drag the whole party into fae bargains.

## ⚖️ Core Themes in His Story
* **Accidental Prophet:** Once seen as divine, now a wandering ex-messiah who can’t escape his legend.
* **Responsibility Avoided:** Haunted by the child he abandoned and the deaths of his followers.
* **Faith vs. Falsehood:** Unsure whether his current divine calling is real—or just another high.
* **Comedy and Tragedy:** His permanent dazed state makes him ridiculous, but his story carries real pathos.

This version makes Rohandsey’s backstory **tragic, absurd, and gameable**—with the **Trouble Table** serving as a DM’s toolkit to keep his past crashing into the present.

column2: Great crystals that float in the sky
column3:
There are several giant crystals that float high in the sky among the clouds.  They move around the world, as though they may float on the wind. It is hard to know how many there are as they move.  There may be 100 or so or maybe only 20.

Gargantuan crystals float through the air, approx 100m tall, 20m wide, tapered towards the top.  Nobody knows how many there are as they move around randomly and look alike, but estimates sit between 20 and 40 across the world.  Some appear to be damaged with cracks across their surface, and some with whole pieces missing.  They have been there as long as written history.  Nobody knows their purpose, but there are theories. 
Theories:
- They make the rain -  some people pray for one to appear and bring rain
- They bring wind and storms -  and their coming means a storm is coming
- A great long lost empire built them then forgot about them
- They are not of this world -  they got lost from another dimension
- They charge up the lightning

Secret:  they are power packs for the Riftborn -  by attuning to one, grants a deep well of arcane power to call on (like giant spell slots).  Used to power 20th level magic.  If you attune to one it will gradually travel towards you then hover above you.  Once attuned you can turn it invisible so that it does not give your location away.  Attuning to it gives you 5 9th level spell slots

What an NPC knows:
- There are several () of these giant floating crystals around the world. I once saw two of them hanging near each other, a deep red one, and a light blue one.
- They all are different colours -  don’t know why they would have different colours.  But you can use them to identify them
- People have nicknamed them - red ones are known as blood blades, blue one are sky dreams, green ones is Sylvanus’ Spires, yellow ones are ____, violet one are viridian flowers, orange ones are sun spires _____, black ones are nightmares because they seem to crackle with malevolent energy.
- Some show signs of damage -  cracks, great rents in their sides, cratered surface
- Current count is 22 -  but not confirmed, because they move around the world randomly, almost with the wind, but not quite.

What people in the world believe about the Forerunners
- An ancient race of beings who are said to have commanded great magical power.
- Not sure that they were actually a race or were they multiple races.  Skeletons have been unearthed in known Forerunner archaeological sites that looked a lot like the peoples of Taeleran today - humans, dwarves, elves, gnomes etc.  
- Left behind great engineering structures - great bridges and dams, massive buildings on mountain peaks - things that could not be built today - the knowledge and engineering techniques and even magic has been lost.
- No trace of what happened to them.  It seems that one day they just disappeared off the face of the planet.
- When they left, there is evidence that their departure unleashed a great magical outburst that left significant scars on the landscape - created massive canyons, craters, sent chunks of earth into the sky and they have remained there floating. Some say the Dark Lands were created by this cataclysm.
- They have left behind several great magic items and a few texts that are the basis of all we know about them - other than children’s stories and myths and legends (although myths often begin with a seed of truth). 
- Nobody knows where their magical power came from - arcane scholars believe their magic may not have been of the weave of magic as we use today for all forms of magic on Taeleran.

Here’s what the PCs would know about The Darklands (generally held knowledge of the world):
An area racked by intense volcanic and geological activity, great storms and gravitic impacts.  Nobody can live there, for most who venture there do not return.  Only a few have survived to return and told of the chaos within.  Lightning cracks regularly, and some of it is a menacing red.
Storms cover the entire sky, making it dim everywhere, hence the name.
Boulders float and huge earthmotes have been lifted out of the ground.  Pieces of rock get thrown around by the gravity storm and the winds, smashing down into the ground.  There is also regular storms of minor pebbles, rattling into the ground like a hail of bullets.  Like a cross between the elemental plane of air and earth and fire, and ice. Seasons switch at a moment, from extreme heat, to icy cold
A great storm sits constantly above the Unknown Lands, called The Everstorm.  It stays in place.
Can't work out how to use it, but able to make it do just one thing that is miraculous e.g. float and defy gravity for a time.  It is kind of bulky.
Goblins rent themselves out either as fighters, or as bum boys.  They will do anything for a shiny coin.  They don't consider it degrading, it's just work.

Gundren Rockseeker is a member, though just a lowly member, a Seeker, of an ancient sacred order.  They call themselves the Wardens of the Void, and they search out and protect the Forerunner’s lost wisdom, relics, and teachings.  They believe that one day, when the world needs them most, the Forerunners will return to claim their legacy and lead the world forth into a golden age. Until that day, the Wardens of the Void stand as silent sentinels, ensuring this knowledge does not fall into the hands of the unworthy.  
The Wardens began as squires to the Knights Radiant of the Forerunners, serving them and supporting them.  When they disappeared from the land, we took up the mission of preserving their legacy so it will be here when they eventually return.
Name comes from the mission of the Forerunners themselves.  The forerunners protected the world from a great threat from the far realm - from the great void space of insanity and unreality.  We continue this responsibility, although much of the knowledge of the forerunners has been lost and we fear we may be losing the battle.  There are rifts across the world.  They are warded to stop entities coming through.  But the order has lost the knowledge to make and maintain the wards.  They seek out rumours of old forerunner caches and archives.
The order's name has changed many times over thousands of years.
Gundren has the symbol of the order tattooed on the inside of his arm.
Percy’s sword has a symbol of the order -  it is an old symbol, not used for many thousands of years, but bears a likeness to our current symbol (below) -  old symbol on percy’s sword seen second below.. The two runes at the bottom represent knowledge and duty: the twin pillars - to preserve the knowledge, and the duty to protect it and keep it hidden from those who would use it for evil.
There is a prophecy that the Forerunners will return one day, when the world needs them most.  And we must protect their secrets until then from those who would use them for evil.  This is the sacred mission of the Wardens.
A chapter house is in Dawnhaven.  THey say the city was built by the Forerunners themselves.  It is a beautiful city, led by the queen
